Nina:

i suspect i've dragged this thread way off course. Mike Kelly and i
=
have had a similar convo many times over the last year or so and i was
real=
ly just "poking the bear" w/ my post; my bad<g>.

suffice to say that, for =
the most part, i concur w/ your observations.

the power and flexibility of=
 machines does not match that of humans;
that is not needed in order to "co=
de" hypermedia agents to accomplish
[selected|limited|simple|etc] tasks on =
behalf of humans.this is
already happening today and will continue to grow =
overtime. most of
the work is being down "outside" the "hypermedia space" r=
ight now, but
i am finding some very interesting research that leads me to =
think
apply hypermedia is not out of the question. [1]

whether "meaning" e=
xists within a message or is derived from the
message by some means ("inter=
pretation", etc.) is well beyond the
scope of this list. my current thought=
s are influenced greatly by the
work of James Gibson[2] and and Donald Norm=
an[3]. i'll leave off this
part of the convo as i have little tangle proof =
for my POV at this
time.

sorry for the detour.

[1] http://en.wikipedia.or=
g/wiki/Software_agent#Examples_of_intelligent_software_agents
[2] http://en=
.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_J._Gibson
[3] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald=
_Norman

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
http://mam=
und.com/foaf.rdf#me

azkova.nina@...> wrote:
> On 3 January 2012 17:52, mike amundsen <mam=
und@...> wrote:
>> Mike:
>>
>> your responses surprise me (only a bit=
<g>) since you are the one
>> person on this list who has designed, and act=
ively promotes, a
>> hyper-media type which you describe as: =A0"...machine=
-readable and
>> designed to be consumed by automated 'agents'."[1]
>>
>
> =
Machine readable doesn't necessarily mean the clients extract emerging
> se=
mantic; they simply can process already encoded semantic.
>

tateless.co/hal_specification.html
>>
>> mca
>> http://amundsen.com/blog/

>>

>>
>>
>>=
 On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 10:42, Mike Kelly <mikekelly321@...> wrote:
>=
>> On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 3:19 PM, mike amundsen <mamund@...> wrote:
=
>>>> <snip>
>>>> Comparison with WWW is not fair. =A0There is a single shar=
ed semantic
>>>> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are =
way better
>>>> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.
>>>> </=
snip>
>>>>
>>>> think about what you say here: that there is a "shared sema=
ntic"
>>>> understanding. and where does this understanding exist? only (an=
d
>>>> solely) in the head of humans?
>>>>
>
>
> One could argue there are =
at least two levels:
> 1) Technically, a common meaning of HTML tags, inter=
preted uniformly
> (well, almost) across browsers
> 2) A shared meaning con=
veyed by the language and visual symbols and
> eventually emerging, yes, in=
 human heads. =A0Eventually, because it
> depends on the context, culture, =
etc.
>
> There is an analogy with 1) uniform POST semantics at the network
=
> level and 2) application meaning from the pov of application.
>
>>>> afte=
r careful review, i claim you will find that there *are*
>>>> real-world ma=
rkers, indicators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
>>>> real world; o=
nes that are recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
>>>> activated by h=
umans. Currently, thesemarkers are the visual cues that
>>>> are rendered b=
y common Web browsers via the messages sent by servers
>>>> in the most ubi=
quitous human-centered hypermedia format of the day;
>>>> HTML.
>>>>
>>>> "=
Semantic meaning" is an emergent property. In the case of HTML that
>>>> pr=
operty is "created" by humans when they observe the visual
>>>> "landscape"=
 rendered by =A0Web browsers.
>
> Not necessarily an emergent property only=
. The meaning can be formally
> defined by humans (by logic, common vocabul=
aries, knowledge
> representation, etc) and encoded in the software. The en=
coded semantic
> essentially constitutes =A0the shared understanding betwee=
n the client
> and the server.
>
>>>>
>>>> Does anyone here want to assert =
that this "semantic meaning" can
>>>> _only_ emerge when humans are *direct=
ly* involved in the real-time
>>>> interpretation of messages that contain =
these (or similar) markers?
>>>
>
> Anybody can create a client, which will=
 read the same HTML tags on a
> web page, but it will hardly be expected th=
ese days to have full human
> reasoning capabilities.
>
>>> Afaict, there's=
 a spectrum of sophistication here. I haven't seen a
>>> client implementat=
ion which demonstrates automated capabilities which
>>> come 'close' to tha=
t of a human, we're basically talking about the
>>> web's version of a Turi=
ng Test.
>>>
>
> Indeed.
>
>>> Most of the evidence so far suggests this is=
 the case, although I am
>>> not an AI expert.
>>>
>>>> Or
>>>> is it possi=
ble that humans can "code" agents to have (at least some
>>>> of) this same=
 ability to recognize, parse, and activate the
>>>> "affordances" found in =
the hypermedia landscape?
>>>>
>>>> It is my assertion that the latter is t=
he case. I also contend that
>>>> making the assumption that this is possib=
le is a key step in advancing
>>>> the art and theory of distributed hyperm=
edia.
>>>>
>
> Well, if regarding hypermedia as one of the instances of kno=
wledge
> representation, this is certainly within the research scope of AI =
/
> machine learning.
>
>>>
>>> I think it's an interesting research topic =
but the complexity of
>>> producing these sorts of clients is so high, it's=
 inevitable that only
>>> a small portion of your client base will behave t=
his way (unless you
>>> control them all, in which case your system is not =
very distributed!).
>>> So, in practice, you will be forced to only evolve =
your application in
>>> a way that caters to the lowest common denominator =
- undermining the
>>> effort that has gone into more sophisticated clients.=
 This is a big
>>> challenge to overcome in and of itself, irrespective of =
the challenge
>>> of inventing the designs for such an autonomous hypermedi=
a agent.
>>>
>
> Agree.
>
> Regards,
> Nina
>
>>> Cheers,
>>> Mike
